title: How to deal with the comments for your blog posts. - Quora

response.answer_text: Not sure what you mean by ‘deal with’. Do you mean volume or emotion? Many people just opt to turn them off these days. In 2018 they aren’t particularly valuable for most sites. My recommendation is to define a set of rules for your community, make them available on your site, and then use them as your yardstick. In doing this you: (a) make your own assessments 100% transparent (b) have a go-to list for when you block people and they email you with complaints or threats instead (yep, it happens, especially if you publish emotional stuff) (c) give people a list against which to assess their own behaviours. They know what’s acceptable and what’s not, and can then choose to behave accordingly.

Simple — I determine the comments on these yardsticks:— If they are constructive (but not necessarily polite), I’ll respond in kind.If they are spam, I’ll remove them unceremoniously.If they are trolling or offensive, I grade them out of 25 marks or remove them.If the comments are potentially defamatory against anyone (including myself), then I screencap them and archive the screencaps as evidence for possible use later.If the comments are potentially in breach of the law (both of the physical location of my blog server computers and of my current location), I repeat Step 3 above.Getting inelegant and problematic comments is part and parcel of the life of blogging. Don’t let that affect your blogging efforts. If one is fearful of getting negative comments, then blogging isn’t a worthwhile thing to do.
